title: I'm a Forest Ranger. Strange Things Come Out at Night.
full_text: I tugged at the collar of my ranger uniform one more time before pulling open the passenger door of the patrol vehicle. The fabric still felt stiff against my neck, and I wondered if it would ever feel natural wearing it. Three weeks into the job and I was still adjusting everything twice before it felt right. Alfred Fowler was already behind the wheel, checking his radio and making notes on his clipboard. He looked up when I climbed in, giving me a quick nod. The guy had been doing this for nearly 20 years, and it showed in how he moved, everything deliberate, practiced. His uniform looked like it had been tailored specifically for him, while mine still felt like I was wearing someone else's clothes. "Ready for another exciting evening in paradise?" Alfred asked, turning the key in the ignition. I buckled my seatbelt and settled back into the seat. "Ready as I'll ever be." The engine rumbled to life and Alfred pulled us out of the ranger station parking lot. I watched the building disappear in the side mirror, its lights growing smaller as we headed toward the main forest roads. This was my fourth patrol with Alfred and I was starting to get a feel for the routine; check the popular camping areas, make sure the fire restrictions were being followed, keep an eye out for anything unusual. So far, the most exciting thing we'd encountered was a family of raccoons that had figured out how to open a particularly stubborn cooler. Alfred steered us onto the main access road that wound deeper into Cascade National Forest. The trees pressed in on both sides, their branches creating a canopy overhead that blocked out most of the remaining daylight. I'd grown up in the city where the tallest thing around was a five-story apartment building. Being surrounded by these massive Douglas firs and western hemlocks still felt overwhelming sometimes. "See that clearing up ahead on the left?" Alfred pointed through the windshield as we approached a break in the tree line. I leaned forward to get a better look. "Yeah, I see it." "That's where we had the bear incident last summer. Family from Portland decided to set up camp right there even though there were signs posted about bear activity in the area. Mother bear with two cubs came through around midnight looking for food." "What happened?" Alfred slowed the vehicle as we passed the clearing. "Nobody got hurt, thankfully. But the family lost most of their supplies and we had to escort them out of the forest. Spent the next three days tracking the bears to make sure they hadn't gotten too comfortable around human food." I made a mental note about the location. Alfred had been doing this kind of thing since I started, pointing out spots where things had happened, sharing stories about past incidents. I figured it was his way of teaching me what to watch for, helping me understand the forest and the people who came through it. We continued down the winding road and Alfred kept up his informal tour guide routine. He pointed out a trailhead where they'd had to rescue a hiker with a broken ankle two months ago. Then a spot where someone had tried to build an illegal campfire during the height of fire season. Each story came with details about what had gone wrong and how they'd handled it. "The thing about this job," Alfred said as we rounded another bend, "is that most people think the forest is just like a city park. They don't understand that out here, a small mistake can turn into a big problem real fast." I nodded, though I wasn't sure I fully grasped what he meant yet. My training had covered emergency procedures and safety protocols, but Alfred's stories made it clear that the real education happened out here on patrol. The radio crackled with a brief check-in from another ranger unit and Alfred responded with our location and status. Everything normal, everything quiet. I was starting to understand why some of the more experienced rangers called these evening patrols windshield time, long stretches of driving through empty forest roads watching for problems that usually weren't there. "That trail marker up there," Alfred said gesturing toward a wooden sign barely visible in the growing dusk, "leads to one of the more remote camping areas. We'll need to check that tomorrow during the day shift. Too easy to miss things when it's getting dark." I tried to read the sign as we passed but the light was fading fast. The forest had a different quality at this time of evening. Everything seemed quieter, more closed in. During my daytime patrols, the woods felt open and welcoming. Now with shadows stretching across the road and the canopy blocking out most of the sky, it felt like we were driving through a tunnel. Alfred turned on the headlights and the beams cut through the gathering darkness ahead of us. I watched the white lines of the road disappear under our vehicle, hypnotized by the steady rhythm of our progress. The radio stayed quiet and the only sounds were the engine and the occasional creak of the vehicle's suspension as we hit bumps in the asphalt. "You getting used to the night shifts yet?" Alfred asked. "I think so. It's different than I expected." "Different how?" I thought about how to explain it. "Quieter, I guess. During the day there's always something happening. Hikers asking for directions, families setting up camps, people fishing at the lake. At night it feels like we're the only people for miles." Alfred nodded. "That's because we probably are. Most folks don't realize how big this forest actually is. You could walk for days without seeing another person if you knew where to go." The idea made me slightly uncomfortable, though I couldn't pinpoint why. Maybe it was just the newness of it all, being responsible for such a vast area, knowing that if something went wrong out here, help could be a long way off.We approached another curve in the road, this one sharper than the others we'd navigated. Alfred slowed down as we came around it. The headlights sweeping across the trees on the far side. That's when I saw it. Standing directly in the middle of the road, maybe 50 yards ahead of us, was a figure unlike anything I'd ever seen. It had to be at least eight feet tall, maybe more, with arms that hung down past where its knees should be. The proportions were all wrong. The torso too long, the head misshapen and tilted at an odd angle. It wasn't moving, just standing there in our headlight beams like it was waiting for something. My first thought was that someone was playing a prank, maybe wearing some kind of costume or stilts. But as we got closer, I could see that whatever this was, it wasn't human. The way it stood was too still, too unnatural. No person could maintain that posture, and no costume could create those proportions. "What is that?" I asked, leaning forward in my seat to get a better look. Alfred's hands tightened on the steering wheel, and I noticed his foot had moved to the brake pedal. "Turn around," he said. His voice suddenly urgent. "What?" "Turn around now." I looked at him, confused. "Shouldn't we check if someone needs help? Maybe it's..." "Turn around." Alfred's voice was sharp, more forceful than I'd ever heard it. The intensity in his tone caught me off guard. This was the same guy who'd been calmly telling stories and pointing out landmarks just minutes ago. Now, he looked tense, almost panicked. "Alfred, what's going on?" But he was already spinning the wheel, executing a quick three-point turn in the narrow road. The headlights swept across the trees as we turned, and for a moment, everything was shadows and confusion. When we completed the turn and I looked back toward where the figure had been standing, the road was empty, completely empty. I twisted in my seat trying to see if the thing had moved into the trees or stepped off the road, but there was nothing there. Just empty asphalt stretching back into the darkness. "Where did it go?" I asked. Alfred didn't answer. He was focused on driving, taking us back the way we'd come at a speed that seemed faster than necessary. His jaw was set, and he kept glancing in the rear-view mirror. The radio crackled and the dispatcher's voice filled the vehicle. "Unit seven, what's your status?" Alfred grabbed the radio without hesitation. "Unit seven, all clear. Continuing patrol." All clear? I stared at him. We'd just seen something that definitely wasn't clear, something that didn't make any sense at all. But Alfred was acting like nothing had happened. "Alfred," I said, keeping my voice low even though there was nobody else around to hear us. "What was that thing back there?" "Nothing." "That wasn't nothing. That was..." "Drop it, Bryce." His tone made it clear the conversation was over, but I couldn't just let it go. I'd seen what I'd seen, and pretending it hadn't happened wasn't going to make it disappear from my memory. "Look, I know something was standing in that road. Something big. And when we turned around, it was gone. Things don't just vanish like that." Alfred kept driving, his eyes fixed on the road ahead. For a long moment, I thought he wasn't going to respond at all. Then he spoke, his voice quiet but firm. "Some things in these woods are better left alone, Bryce. You'd do well to remember that." The way he said it made my skin crawl. It wasn't just advice. It was a warning. And the fact that he wouldn't even acknowledge what we'd both clearly seen made it worse somehow. I settled back in my seat, but my mind was racing. What kind of animal could stand upright like that? What kind of person could be that tall with those proportions? And how had it disappeared so completely in the few seconds it took us to turn around? Alfred reached for the radio again and called in our position, reporting that we were heading back toward the main station. His voice was steady and professional, giving no indication that anything unusual had happened. But I could see his hands on the steering wheel, and they were gripping it tighter than they needed to be. I barely made it through the front door of the Ranger station before hearing my name called from across the main office. "Johnston, my office now." Raymond Santiago's voice carried that particular tone that meant trouble, the kind of tone that made every other ranger in the building suddenly find their paperwork incredibly fascinating. I caught a few sideways glances as I walked past the duty desk, but nobody made eye contact. That wasn't a good sign. The chief's office sat at the back of the building, separated from the main floor by a wall of windows that he kept covered with Venetian blinds. I'd only been inside twice before, once during my initial interview and once for my first week check-in. Both times had been routine, professional. This didn't feel routine. Raymond stood behind his desk when I knocked on the door frame. He was a big man, the kind of presence that filled a room even when he wasn't trying. Completely bald with a thick salt and pepper beard that made his steel blue eyes look even more intense. His ranger uniform was perfectly pressed. Every insignia and badge positioned exactly where regulation demanded. "Close the door behind you." I did as instructed and took the chair across from his desk without being asked.The office was exactly what you'd expect from a man who'd spent 30 years working his way up through the ranks. Commendations on the walls, photographs of him with various officials, a bookshelf filled with policy manuals and forestry guides, everything organized and purposeful. Raymond didn't sit down. Instead, he picked up a manila folder from his desk and opened it, scanning whatever was inside. The silence stretched long enough that I started wondering if I was supposed to say something first, but my gut told me to keep quiet and let him lead. "Alfred filed a report about your conduct yesterday evening." The words hit me like cold water. "A report? About my conduct?" I tried to keep my expression neutral, but my mind was already racing. What could Alfred have possibly written? We'd completed the patrol, returned to the station, filed the logs. Everything had been by the book except for... "He indicates you showed poor judgment during a routine patrol situation. Specifically, that you wanted to abandon protocol and investigate what turned out to be nothing more than shadows and poor lighting conditions." There it was. Alfred had filed a report, but he twisted what actually happened, made it sound like I'd been seeing things, like I'd wanted to chase shadows instead of following proper procedure. The careful way Raymond was phrasing it told me Alfred had been very deliberate about how he'd described the incident. "Sir, I think there might be some confusion about what we encountered." "There's no confusion, Johnston." Raymond's voice cut through my words like a blade. "Alfred has 18 years of experience in these woods. You have three weeks. When he tells me that a rookie ranger wanted to waste time and resources investigating nothing, I believe him." The dismissal in his tone stung, but what bothered me more was how quickly he'd shut down any attempt at explanation, like he'd already decided what version of events he was going to accept before I'd even walked into the room. "I understand that, sir, but what we saw wasn't shadows or poor lighting. There was something..." "Stop right there." Raymond closed the folder and finally sat down, leaning back in his chair. His eyes never left mine, and I could feel the weight of his attention like a physical thing. When he spoke again, his voice was quieter, but somehow more menacing. "Let me tell you something about working in the forest, Johnston, especially at night. The mind plays tricks. Shadows move in ways that don't make sense. Trees look like people. Rocks look like animals. Wind sounds like voices. It happens to everyone, even experienced rangers." He was giving me an out, a way to agree with his version of events and make this whole conversation go away. But the thing we'd seen hadn't been a shadow or a trick of the light. It had been real, solid, massive. And Alfred's reaction had been immediate and visceral, like he'd recognized exactly what he was looking at. "I know what I saw, sir." The temperature in the room seemed to drop several degrees. Raymond's expression didn't change, but something shifted behind his eyes, something that made my skin crawl. "No, you don't." His voice was barely above a whisper now. "Because if you did know what you saw, you'd understand why it's important to keep your mouth shut about it." The words hung in the air between us like a physical presence. This wasn't professional guidance anymore. This was something else entirely. A warning, maybe, or a threat. "Your job as a ranger is to protect the public and preserve the forest. Sometimes that means responding to emergencies. Sometimes it means enforcing regulations, and sometimes it means knowing when to mind your own business and follow your partner's lead." Raymond opened a desk drawer and pulled out a different folder, this one thicker than the first. He set it on the desk between us, but didn't open it. "Alfred is one of the best rangers I've ever worked with. He knows these woods better than anyone, and he's got good instincts about when something is worth pursuing and when it's better left alone. You'd do well to listen to him." The way he emphasized "better left alone" made it clear we weren't just talking about general ranger duties anymore. This was about the figure in the road, about Alfred's immediate decision to turn around and leave, about the false report he'd radioed in afterward. "I need to know that you understand what I'm telling you, Johnston." I met his eyes and tried to read what was really happening here. Raymond Santiago had been chief for over a decade. He'd built a reputation for running a tight operation, for maintaining order and discipline. But this conversation felt like it was about something much bigger than a rookie ranger questioning his partner's judgment. "I understand that you want me to follow Alfred's lead." "That's part of it." Raymond leaned forward, placing his hands flat on the desk. "The other part is that I need to know you're not going to waste my time with reports about things that don't exist. This department responds to actual emergencies, lost hikers, injured campers, illegal hunting, real problems that require real solutions." He paused, letting that sink in before continuing. "We don't chase shadows. We don't investigate every strange noise or unusual sight that might or might not be something worth worrying about. And we definitely don't file reports about encounters with things that can't be explained or verified."The message was crystal clear. Whatever we'd seen on Timber Ridge Road was off limits, not just for discussion, but for any kind of official acknowledgement. Raymond was telling me that certain things didn't get reported, didn't get investigated, didn't get talked about. "Do I make myself clear?" "Yes, sir." "Good." Raymond closed both folders and slid them into his desk drawer. "Alfred speaks highly of your potential as a Ranger. Don't make him regret recommending you for this position." Alfred had recommended me? That was news. During my interview process, I'd been told that my application had been reviewed by multiple senior staff members, but nobody had mentioned specific recommendations. The fact that Alfred had vouched for me before we'd even met added another layer to whatever was happening here. "You can go." I stood up and headed for the door, but Raymond's voice stopped me before I could leave. "Johnston, one more thing." I turned back to face him. "The woods can be dangerous, especially for someone who doesn't know them well. Stick close to your partner. Follow his lead. And remember that sometimes, the best way to handle a situation is to walk away from it." I nodded and left his office, closing the door behind me. The main floor of the station buzzed with normal activity, rangers checking equipment, reviewing patrol schedules, filing reports. Everything looked exactly the same as it had 15 minutes earlier, but something fundamental had changed. Walking back to my desk, I tried to process what had just happened. Raymond had essentially told me that certain encounters weren't supposed to be reported or investigated, that there were things in the forest that were better left alone, and that my job security depended on accepting that reality without question. But the most unsettling part wasn't what he'd said. It was how he'd said it, like he was speaking from experience, like he'd had this exact conversation before with other rangers who'd seen things they weren't supposed to see. I spent the rest of the morning trying to focus on routine paperwork, but my mind kept drifting back to the figure in the road and Raymond's ominous warnings. Every time another ranger walked past my desk, I wondered if they'd had similar encounters, if they'd been called into the chief's office and given the same speech about minding their own business and following their partner's lead. Around noon, I was reviewing trail maintenance schedules when I felt someone approach my desk. I looked up to find Alfred standing there, his expression unreadable. "How'd your meeting with Santiago go?" The question was casual enough, but there was something in his eyes that suggested he already knew the answer, or at least knew what kind of conversation we'd had. "Fine. Just routine feedback about following proper protocols." Alfred nodded slowly like he was evaluating my response. "Good. Raymond's a fair chief, but he expects his rangers to understand the bigger picture." The bigger picture, another vague reference to something beyond normal ranger duties. I was starting to feel like everyone around me was speaking in code, referencing shared knowledge that I wasn't privy to. "Listen, Bryce," Alfred glanced around the office, making sure nobody was within earshot. "You got plans tomorrow night after shift?" "Nothing specific. Why?" "Meet me at Murphy's Bar around 8:00. There's something I need to tell you, something important." Murphy's Bar was a local place about 10 minutes from the station, the kind of establishment where off-duty rangers and other forest service employees went to unwind. I'd been there once since starting the job, just to get a feel for the local scene. "What kind of something?" Alfred's expression grew more serious. "The kind that's better discussed away from here, away from official channels." He was talking about the figure again, had to be. This was his way of addressing what had really happened on Timber Ridge Road, away from Santiago's oversight and the official reporting structure. "Okay, eight o'clock at Murphy's." "Good." Alfred started to walk away, then turned back. "And Bryce?" "Donhh." Not Santiago, not the other rangers, nobody. I watched him return to his desk and tried to make sense of what was happening. First, Raymond had essentially threatened me to keep quiet about what we'd encountered. Now Alfred was arranging a secret meeting to discuss something important. The two conversations felt connected, but I couldn't figure out how they fit together. The rest of the day dragged by with excruciating slowness. Every routine task felt meaningless compared to the questions burning in my mind. What was Alfred planning to tell me? Why did it have to be discussed in secret? And what exactly had Raymond meant when he talked about things that were better left alone? By the time my shift ended, I was wound tight with anticipation and anxiety. The drive home felt longer than usual, and I found myself checking the rear-view mirror more often than necessary, like I was being followed, even though I knew that was paranoid thinking. My apartment was a small one-bedroom place about 20 minutes from the station. Basic, but comfortable enough for someone just starting out. I'd moved there specifically for the ranger job, leaving behind a desk position with the State Environmental Agency that had been slowly crushing my soul with bureaucracy and meaningless paperwork. I heated up leftover pizza and tried to watch television, but concentration was impossible. My mind kept cycling through the day's events, trying to find patterns or explanations that made sense.... Alfred's behavior during the encounter, Raymond's veiled threats, the secret meeting tomorrow night. It all felt connected to something much larger than a simple patrol incident. Around 10 o'clock, I gave up on television and went to bed, hoping that sleep would provide some relief from the endless speculation. But lying in the dark only made things worse. Every small sound from outside made me tense up. Every shadow that moved across the ceiling from passing headlights reminded me of the massive figure standing motionless in the road. I kept thinking about Alfred's reaction when he'd seen it, the immediate recognition in his eyes like he'd encountered something similar before, the way he'd ordered me to turn around without any hesitation or discussion. And then the false radio report covering up what had actually happened. How many other encounters had been covered up? How many other rangers had seen things they weren't supposed to report? And what exactly was lurking in the forest that required such elaborate secrecy? The questions multiplied in the darkness, each one leading to three more. I tried counting sheep, tried focusing on my breathing, tried every relaxation technique I could remember. Nothing worked. My mind was too wired, too full of unanswered questions and half-formed theories. Around midnight, I got up and made myself a cup of tea, hoping the ritual would calm my nerves. Standing in the kitchen, looking out at the dark trees beyond my apartment complex, I couldn't shake the feeling that something was watching me, which was ridiculous, of course. I was miles from the forest, surrounded by other buildings and streetlights, but the feeling persisted, like invisible eyes were tracking my movements, studying me from somewhere beyond the reach of artificial light. I closed the blinds and returned to bed, but sleep remained elusive. When I finally drifted off sometime after 2:00 in the morning, my dreams were filled with massive figures standing in dark roads, their misshapen heads tilted at impossible angles. And behind them, in the deeper shadows between the trees, other shapes moved with patient, predatory grace. I woke up several times throughout the night, each time with the distinct impression that something had been calling my name from outside. But when I listened carefully, all I could hear was the normal sounds of wind and distant traffic. By morning, I felt like I'd barely slept at all. My eyes were gritty and my head ached from too much thinking and not enough rest. But at least the long night was over, and tonight I'd finally get some answers. Whatever Alfred had to tell me at Murphy's Bar, it had to be better than the endless speculation and unanswered questions that were driving me slowly insane. Even if the truth turned out to be more disturbing than I'd imagined, at least I'd know what I was dealing with. I just hoped I was ready for whatever he was planning to reveal. I pulled into Murphy's Bar parking lot just after 8:00, gravel crunching under my tires as I found a spot near the back. The place looked exactly like what you'd expect from a dive bar on the outskirts of town. Weathered wooden siding, neon beer signs flickering in grimy windows, and the kind of atmosphere that suggested most conversations here were meant to stay private. Walking through the front door, I let my eyes adjust to the dim lighting. The smell of stale beer and cigarette smoke hung in the air despite the smoking ban, probably soaked into the wood paneling after decades of use. A few locals sat at the bar nursing drinks and watching a baseball game on the mounted television. Their voices are low murmur that mixed with the jukebox playing some old country song I didn't recognize. I spotted Alfred immediately. He sat in the far corner booth, his back to the wall with a clear view of both the entrance and the rest of the bar. Classic positioning for someone who didn't want to be surprised or overheard. Even in civilian clothes, a faded flannel shirt and worn jeans, he still carried himself with that ranger alertness, though something about his posture seemed different tonight. As I approached his table, I noticed the glass in front of him. Whiskey from the amber color, and definitely not his first based on how he was nursing it. Alfred wasn't much of a drinker during our patrols together. He'd mentioned once that he preferred to keep his head clear when dealing with the unpredictable nature of forest work. Seeing him here deliberately working his way through what looked like expensive bourbon told me this conversation was going to be heavier than I'd anticipated. "Bryce." He looked up as I slid into the booth across from him. "Thanks for coming." "Of course." I flagged down the waitress and ordered a beer, more to have something to do with my hands than because I wanted alcohol. "You sounded like this was important." Alfred nodded, his fingers tightening around his glass. That's when I really got a good look at his face. The fluorescent light above our booth was harsh and unflattering, but it couldn't hide what I was seeing. Fear, not the healthy caution that came with years of dealing with dangerous wildlife or unpredictable weather conditions. This was something deeper, more personal. The kind of fear that comes from knowing exactly what you're afraid of and having good reason to be afraid of it. "It is important." He took another sip of whiskey, grimaced slightly, then set the glass down with deliberate care. "What we saw out there the other night, that wasn't the first time."I felt my stomach tighten. Part of me had suspected as much from his reaction, but hearing him confirm it made everything more real. "When?" "Seven years ago." Alfred's voice dropped lower, forcing me to lean forward to catch his words over the ambient noise of the bar. "I had a different partner then. Miles Allen. Good man, experienced ranger. Been on the job for about 15 years at that point." The waitress brought my beer, and I took a long pull while Alfred gathered his thoughts. I could see him working through whatever he was about to tell me. His eyes focused on something beyond the grimy window beside our booth. "We were doing a night patrol, same route we took the other evening, same section of forest road where we encountered that thing." He paused, seeming to weigh his words carefully. "Miles was driving that night. I was in the passenger seat doing radio checks when he suddenly hit the brakes." Alfred's hand moved to his glass again, but he didn't pick it up, just traced the rim with one finger while he continued. "There it was, standing right in the middle of the road. Same spot, near as I could tell. Just like what we saw with you." "Same creature?" "Had to be." Alfred's eyes met mine, and I saw something there that made my chest tighten. Not just fear, but certainty. The kind of absolute knowledge that comes from experiencing something so distinctive, so impossible that there's no chance of mistaking it for anything else. Eight feet tall, arms too long for any human being, head tilted at that unnatural angle. "But this time..." He trailed off, reaching for his whiskey and downing what remained in one swallow. I waited, knowing better than to push. Alfred had always been methodical in his explanations during our patrols, taking time to make sure he communicated clearly. But this felt different. This felt like a man trying to find words for something that shouldn't exist. "This time, it moved," he finally continued. "Not away from us like you might expect. Toward us. Alongside the vehicle." I felt the hair on the back of my neck stand up. "Alongside?" "Miles was backing up, trying to turn around, same as I did with you. But this thing, it kept pace with us, walking parallel to the driver's side, maybe 20 feet out in the trees, just matching our speed perfectly like it was escorting us." Alfred signaled the waitress for another whiskey. I noticed his hand wasn't entirely steady when he raised it. "Miles had a spotlight mounted on his side of the vehicle. Big halogen beam, the kind we use for wildlife counts. He hit the switch and swept it across the trees, trying to get a better look." The waitress brought Alfred's drink, and he immediately took a sip before continuing. "That's when we both got a clear view of it. And Bryce," he looked directly at me, his voice dropping even lower. "What we saw wasn't human, wasn't anything that should exist." I found myself leaning forward, despite every instinct telling me I didn't want to hear this. "What did it look like?" "The face was all wrong. Twisted, like someone had taken human features and rearranged them without understanding how they were supposed to fit together. Eyes too far apart, mouth that stretched too wide, nose that looked like it had been broken and healed crooked multiple times." Alfred's fingers tightened around his glass. "But the worst part was the arms. They hung down past its knees, ending in hands that were more like claws. Long fingers with joints that bent in ways that shouldn't be possible." He paused to take another drink, and I used the break to process what he was telling me. The figure I'd seen had been disturbing enough in the brief glimpse I'd gotten, but Alfred was describing something far more detailed and far more terrifying. "Miles was fascinated by it," Alfred continued. "You know how some people get around dangerous wildlife? That mix of fear and curiosity that makes them want to get closer instead of backing away? That was Miles. He kept the spotlight trained on it, following its movement through the trees." "What happened then?" "It stopped." Alfred's voice took on a hollow quality that made me think he was reliving the memory rather than just recounting it. "Just came to a complete halt, maybe 50 yards ahead of us, right at the edge of the spotlight beam. Miles stopped the vehicle too, and we both sat there watching it." Alfred stared into his whiskey glass like he might find answers there. "Then it turned toward us. Looked right at the vehicle, right at that spotlight beam. And I swear, Bryce, it was looking directly at Miles, like it knew exactly who was behind that light." I felt my mouth go dry. "What did you do?" "I told Miles we needed to leave. Right then, no discussion. Just get the hell out of there and report it when we got back to the station." Alfred's laugh was bitter and humorless. "But Miles wouldn't listen. Said we had a responsibility to investigate. That whatever this thing was, it might pose a threat to hikers or campers in the area." The way Alfred said it made my stomach drop. I could already sense where this story was heading, and I didn't like it. "You wanted to follow it." "Against my better judgment, yes. Miles was senior to me then, had more experience, more authority. When he made the call to pursue, I couldn't override him."Alfred's voice carried the weight of seven years of regret. "We got out of the vehicle and followed it into the trees." I took another long pull of my beer, trying to steady my nerves for whatever was coming next. "How far did you go?" "Maybe a quarter mile. The thing moved through the forest like it owned every inch of it, never stumbling over roots or getting caught on branches. Just gliding between the trees with that unnatural gait, always staying just at the edge of our flashlight range." Alfred's eyes had gone distant again. "Miles was documenting everything, taking photos with his camera, making notes about the creature's behavior and movement patterns, treating it like a wildlife observation instead of..." "Instead of what?" "Instead of what it actually was." Alfred met my eyes again, and the fear I saw there was mixed with something else now. Guilt, deep consuming guilt that had clearly been eating at him for years. A predator, and we were walking right into its territory. The jukebox had switched to a different song. Something slower and more melancholy that seemed to match the mood at our table. I found myself glancing around the bar, noting the other patrons and their conversations, anything to avoid thinking too hard about what Alfred was describing. "It happened fast," Alfred continued. "One moment Miles was ahead of me, following the creature through a dense section of undergrowth. The next moment, I heard him scream." I felt my chest tighten. "It attacked him. I never saw the actual attack. By the time I pushed through the brush to where Miles had been, there was just... evidence. Broken branches, disturbed ground. His camera lying in the dirt with the lens cracked." Alfred's voice became even quieter. "And blood. Not a lot, but enough to know something violent had happened." "What about Miles?" "Gone. Him and the creature, both just gone. Like they'd vanished into thin air." Alfred finished his second whiskey and set the glass down with a soft clink. "I called out for him, searched the immediate area with my flashlight, but there was nothing. No trail to follow, no sounds, no indication of which direction they'd gone." I tried to imagine being alone in those dark woods, knowing something inhuman had just taken my partner, and felt a chill run down my spine. "What did you do?" "What I should've done from the beginning. Got the hell out of there and called for backup." Alfred's expression was grim. "Search and rescue teams combed that area for three days, brought in tracking dogs, helicopter support, volunteers from town. We covered every square mile within a five-mile radius of where Miles disappeared." "Did you find anything?" "Nothing. No trace of Miles, no sign of the creature, no evidence that anything unusual had happened in those woods at all." Alfred's hands clenched into fists on the table.
